Award.AwardTitle: Atomic Junction: Nuclear Power in an African Suburb

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Atomic Junction: Nuclear Power in an African Suburb

This project investigates how Ghanaian scientists have sustained a movement to develop nuclear energy in a suburban landscape over the past forty years. The starting hypothesis is that scientists have nurtured a dream for nuclear energy while providing important services in radiation protection at medical facilities. Preliminary research suggests that the scientific and commercial sectors in Ghana have become increasingly embedded and co-dependent.
Through an examination of scientists, community leaders and their relationship with commercial interests, the project will greatly expand our understanding of scientific practice in a post-colonial nation and provide new avenues for nuclear energy policy.
Ghana has witnessed a variety of financial policies since independence from the United Kingdom in 1957, including socialist and neo-liberal regimes. This project will provide important documentation of how scientists have managed to weather economic downturns. Methods include collecting archival materials and conducting interviews with select leaders in business and science engaged in efforts to develop alternative energy sources and monitor radiation at hospitals and clinics. While energy production is a future goal, the study examines how scientists with access to a 30kW miniature neutron source reactor (the GHAAR-1) and Cobalt-60 gamma source currently provide assistance to entrepreneurs in the agricultural and medical sectors. Deliverables include a book and short film examine the historical relationship between scientific research on atomic energy and commerce in and around Kwabenya, Ghana (an area popularly called Atomic Junction).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project, “Atomic Junction: Nuclear Power in an African Suburb,” provides a historical analysis of radiation protection and nuclear innovation in the West African country of Ghana. Particularly, the study identifies political and social trends surrounding atomic energy and medical isotopes in an African context. The research shows that Ghanaian scientists emerged as a leaders in nuclear physics in West Africa. The final products of the project include articles, a book in progress, and accompanying short film. Funding for this research provided for faculty research, graduate student training, archival trips, and conference presentations in Ghana, the United Kingdom, China, and Russia.

This historical and ethnographic account of the physics in Ghana extends work on nuclear power in South Africa, and emerging countries including India. It emphasizes the role of African scientists at the helm of research. It opens up new strategies for considering scientific work in non-West settings, particularly in Africa, within the discipline of the History of Science. The project is also critical to African History. It bridges the colonial and postcolonial periods, highlighting the roles of independence leaders like Kwame Nkrumah in sponsoring scientific research.

The introduction of visual anthropology and documentary film allows for the wider dissemination of the research material beyond scholars who read the History of Science literature.
